EmailTemplate.subject: Budget 2014 analysis: George finds a pound, but not much for construction
EmailTemplate.textOnly:
George finds a pound coin down the back of the sofa but not enough for construction
The 2014 Budget was inevitably destined to provide a platform for George Osborne to set out his pre-election agenda. Few people will find many words in his headline statement that were not carefully, and in some cases, comically, crafted to provide a basis for electioneering sound bites with both the General Election and Scottish Independence vote due in the next 14 months.
Fiscal constraints continue to dominate and it is clear that austerity Britain is set to remain for many years. Continuing growth helps to justify the more confident mood of the UK economy - a mood that now even extends beyond the separate and dominant economy of London and the South East. Investment in Mersey Gateway and some housing, with continued support to science and research and the energy and utilities sectors will help improve the lots of the regions.
As we highlighted in our 2013 Autumn Statement commentary, the output gap shows no sign of reducing. This gives not only concern for longer term productivity and the UK’s competitiveness, but for the construction industry it provides a big challenge as it is now looked on to deliver. The welcome investment in more apprenticeships will help, but how many will apply to the construction industry and the timing of their impact is also in question?
